PERSPECTIVE Promoting effect exerted by WOx on Pt/ZrO2 catalysts during NOx reduction using H2 in the excess of O2 Enno Eßer Daniel Schröder Sven Kureti ⁎ Technical University of Freiberg, Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering, Chair of Reaction Engineering, Fuchsmühlenweg 9, 09599 Freiberg, Germany Technical University of Freiberg Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering Chair of Reaction Engineering Fuchsmühlenweg 9 09599 Freiberg Germany Technical University of Freiberg, Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering, Chair of Reaction Engineering, Fuchsmühlenweg 9, 09599 Freiberg, Germany ⁎ Corresponding author at: Technical University of Freiberg, Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering, Chair of Reaction Engineering, Fuchsmühlenweg 9, 09599 Freiberg, Germany. Technical University of Freiberg Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering Chair of Reaction Engineering Fuchsmühlenweg 9 09599 Freiberg Germany Graphical abstract This work addresses the reduction of NOx by H2 under O2-rich conditions below 200 °C using Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts with tungsten loadings from 0 to 14 wt%. Samples were thoroughly characterized by N2 physisorption, temperature-programmed desorption of CO, X-ray diffraction, laser Raman spectroscopy and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) with CO as probe molecule. Catalytic investigations showed the highest efficiency for the sample with 5 wt% W providing NOx conversion of 94 % and N2O selectivity of 15 %. The effect of W promoter is mostly attributed to structural promotion by isolated WO6 entities stabilizing the ZrO2 surface and leading to a high number of active Pt sites. By contrast, negligible electronic interaction between the promoter and Pt sites appears. Moreover, DRIFTS studies suggest that, in addition to the predominate NOx reduction by H2 on Pt sites, a side reaction occurs including NHx species formed at the interface of Pt and WOx/ZrO2. Keywords NOx reduction H2 reductant NH3 formation Pt catalyst ZrO2 support WOx promoter Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The defossilization of chemical and energy feedstocks is an important transformation process modern societies are going through to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. In particular, with an 8.2 Gt CO2 equivalent in 2018, the transport sector contributes significantly to the GHG output [1] and is therefore subject to legislative regulations worldwide. For instance, in the European Union, heavy-duty vehicles (>16 t) must achieve a CO2 reduction of 30 % by 2030 compared to 2019 [2]. Thus, battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and H2 fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) are widely being developed and applied. Gasoline and diesel vehicles operating with synthetic fuels employing Power-to-X technologies [3,4] and H2 internal combustion engines (H2–ICEs) are also taken into consideration. The hydrogen fuel for H2-ICEs can be sustainably produced by electrolyzing H2O, powered by photovoltaics, wind generators or hydropower. H2-ICEs are of particular interest for trucks and busses as the H2 supply infrastructure can be implemented rapidly, for instance by using central storage devices operated by municipalities or delivery companies. Additionally, there is advanced knowledge on H2 combustion engines [5,6]. However, one issue affecting H2-ICEs is the emission of NO, originating in the high temperatures inside the combustion chamber (“thermal NO”). The formation of NO can be diminished by engine modifications including H2 combustion at high air–fuel ratios (λ ≥ 2) and cooled high-pressure exhaust gas recirculation (HP-EGR) [5–7]. Despite these internal reduction processes, efficient after-treatment of the exhaust gas will be required to meet NOx emission limits such as the prospective Euro VII, which is expected to set a limit of approx. 0.2 g/kWh for heavy-duty vehicles and busses, halving the current Euro VI threshold [8]. To remove NOx from the lean exhaust gases of heavy-duty vehicles, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is a well-established technique. The SCR process includes the reduction of NO using NH3 to yield N2 and H2O by means of the standard SCR reaction (4 NO + 4 NH3 + O2 → 4 N2 + 6 H2O) at temperatures between approx. 250 and 450 °C using V2O5/WO3/TiO2 (VWT) [9] or Fe-/Cu-zeolites [10]. Moreover, an oxidation catalyst is used that is located upstream of the SCR stage and converts NO into NO2, enabling the fast SCR reaction (2 NH3 + NO + NO2 → 2 N2 + 3 H2O) at temperatures as low as 200 °C. The required ammonia is stored on board the vehicles as an aqueous urea solution, which is converted in the exhaust stream into NH3 and CO2 (CO(NH2)2 + H2O → 2 NH3 + CO2). Basically, the SCR procedure can be transferred to lean H2-ICEs, whereas the hydrothermal long-term stability of the VWT and zeolite catalysts requires a detailed investigation due to the high amounts of H2O present in the H2 engine exhaust gas (up to 15–17 vol%). Additionally, one known limitation of SCR technology is the low NOx reduction performance below 200 °C. Such temperatures become increasingly important due to the increased engine efficiency of up to 46 % [11] as well as the requirements of real driving emission (RDE) tests, which demand deNOx efficiencies up to 90 % even during cold-start and city driving scenarios, in which the exhaust gas temperatures do not exceed 200 °C. In this context, catalytic NOx reduction by means of H2 (H2-deNOx) is a promising concept for the abatement of nitrogen oxides below approx. 220 °C under O2-rich conditions (2 NO (g) + 2 H2 (g) → N2 (g) + 2 H2O (g), ΔH0 = -668 kJ/mol). This technique is not yet established in practice but is currently at the R&D stage. Recently, it has been demonstrated that NOx conversions of up to 90 % can be achieved at exhaust gas temperatures as low as 80 °C in a lean diesel engine exhaust [12]. For H2 combustion engines, H2 is of particular interest as a reducing agent, as it is already available on board and can easily be injected into the exhaust pipe. Some remaining engine slip can also be used. Many studies have reported that Pt is the most active catalytic component for lean H2-deNOx conversion. However, one crucial issue is the marked selectivity for N2O (2 NO (g) + H2 (g) → N2O (g) + H2O (g), ΔH0 = -342 kJ/mol), which is up to 90 % for unpromoted Pt catalysts based on zeolites such as ZSM-5 [13,14] and ZSM-35 [15] or non-reducible binary metal oxides such as Al2O3 [16,17] and SiO2 [18]. For these Pt-based catalysts without promoters, the activity window is typically rather narrow (approx. 50 K), with peak NOx conversions reached at approx. 100 °C. Selectivity for N2 can be affected by replacing Pt with less active but more selective Pd [19–21] and by using support and promoter materials. For instance, Pd- and Pt-containing perovskites with A and B site substitution were reported as effective catalysts, e.g. LaFe0.95–xCoxPd0.05O3 [22], La1–x–ySrxCeyFe0.9Pd0.1O3 [23], Pd/LaCoO3 [24], showing peak NOx conversions up to 95 % with N2 selectivities of 70 % in the temperature range from 100 to 200 °C [23]. Reducible metal oxides such as TiO2 [25], ZrO2 [26] and CeO2 [27,28] have also been studied as carriers for Pt-based catalysts, reaching NOx conversions up to 90 % and N2O selectivities of 70 % between approx. 100 and 250 °C [26]. Moreover, V [29,30], Na [13,31], Mo [18,31,32], K [33,34] and W oxide entities [17,21,25,26,35] have been demonstrated to be effective promoters. Particularly, vanadium-modified Al2O3 [29] and Al2O3/TiO2 [30] carriers have been shown to increase the N2 selectivity up to 92 % at maximal NOx conversions of 98 % [30] using Pd as the active component, while adding tungsten oxide to a HZSM-5 based platinum catalyst [35] increases the N2 selectivity to 74 % at NOx conversions of up to 91 %. Different mechanisms are postulated to explain the beneficial effect of promoters on activity and N2 selectivity. While the existence and participation of active NHx species is assumed for Mo oxide-promoted Pt and V oxide-modified Pd catalysts [29,31], modification with Na seems to enhance the formation of reactive surface nitrites [13]. For a Pt/La0.5Ce0.5MnO3 catalyst, the participation of oxygen vacancies in the vicinity of Pt is also postulated to enhance the NO dissociation, resulting in a maximal N2 selectivity above 85 % [36]. By contrast, Mo [18], K [34] and W oxide [37] moieties are believed to electronically activate the precious metal components. For a Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst, it has been shown that the WOx-promoted Pt sites accelerate the NO dissociation, which is considered the rate-determining step [37]. Similar effects of WOx promotion on Pt-based catalysts have been indicated for different supports such as TiO2 [25], HZSM–5 [35] and Al2O3/SiO2 [17]. Additionally, it has been shown that the selective NOx reduction to N2 is increased by a high dispersion of the active Pt sites. This is related to the mechanistic understanding of the H2-deNOx reaction, which includes the presence of four neighboring Pt atoms for the formation of N2, whereas only three Pt sites are needed to yield N2O [17,38]. Against this background, the present article aims to investigate the nature of the surface WOx species and their role in the H2-deNOx reaction using Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts. To evaluate structure–activity correlations, a series of catalysts with systematically different W loadings and structures were prepared, physico-chemically characterized and investigated to analyze the lean H2-deNOx reaction. The catalysts were examined using N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction, laser Raman spectroscopy, diffuse reflectance UV/Vis spectroscopy and the temperature-programmed desorption of CO. Additionally, the interaction of the WOx species and ZrO2 carrier with the Pt component was investigated using diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy, taking CO as a probe molecule. Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS investigations were performed to provide advanced mechanistic insights into the H2-deNOx reaction on the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation High surface area ZrO2 pellets (111 m2/g) with a monoclinic crystalline structure (3 mm, Alfa Aesar) were used as crude catalyst carriers. Before the sample preparation, the pellets were ground to powder with a vibrating cup mill (Siebtechnik) providing an average particle size of d50 = 8.7 µm as checked by laser diffraction (HELOS, Sympatec). The ZrO2 powder was modified with the active component Pt and the WOx promoter by means of incipient wetness impregnation. For this purpose, a defined volume of an aqueous solution of (NH4)6H2W12O40·H2O (Honeywell) with a known W concentration was added drop by drop to the ZrO2 substrate such that it was completely absorbed. After drying overnight in air at 80 °C, Pt was introduced in a very similar way using a Pt(NO3)2 (Chempur) solution, followed by drying and activating the sample (approx. 4 g) in an H2 flow (10 vol% H2, N2 balance, 400 ml/min (STP)) at 300 °C for 30 min (heating rate: 1.7 K/min). Finally, the catalysts were calcined in static air at 500 °C for 5 h (heating rate: 1.7 K/min). The prepared samples had W proportions of 0, 1, 3, 5, 8, 11 and 14 wt%, while the Pt load was kept at 0.25 wt% for H2-deNOx studies and 2 wt% for spectroscopic investigations in accordance with previous studies [17,26]. For DRUV/Vis analyses, Pt-free samples were also made due to the high adsorption of Pt in the UV/Vis region. Note that the W and Pt mass fractions are related to the bare ZrO2 carrier. The codes of the catalysts used throughout this article reflect the respective Pt and W proportions, e.g. 0.25Pt/5W/ZrO2. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts N2 physisorption was carried out on a TriStar II (Micrometrics). Prior to the analyses, the samples were outgassed in a vacuum (10–1 mbar, 16 h) at 350 °C to remove adsorbed species such as H2O. The BET surface area (SBET) was determined from adsorption data recorded at –196 °C and p/p0 ratios from 0.05 to 0.20. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD) was used to quantify the number of available Pt sites. A sample mass of 0.2 g was introduced into a U-shaped quartz glass reactor, as previously reported for active site measurements of supported metal catalysts [39], and pretreated for 15 min in 5 vol% O2 (He balance), flushed and exposed to 3000 ppm CO (He balance) at 500 °C. The total gas flow was 400 ml/min (STP). This pretreatment was made to remove adsorbed impurities and to fully reduce the Pt surface. Subsequently, the sample was cooled to –196 °C in flowing He, after which exposure to CO (750 ppm, He balance) was started at the same temperature. After saturation, the sample was flushed with He until no more CO was detected in the reactor effluents. The low adsorption temperature of −196 °C was established to avoid CO spilling over from Pt sites to the ZrO2 carrier during the CO saturation, as recently demonstrated for similar supports at −78 °C [40,41]. Preliminary studies have shown that below approx. −127 °C no CO spills over from the Pt particles to the support on tungsten-oxide-promoted Pt/ZrO2 catalysts. Additionally, a significant adsorption of CO on the WOx entity species is not expected even at temperatures as low as –196 °C [42,43]. Finally, the CO-TPD was started by heating to 500 °C at a rate of 20 K/min, adjusting a He flow of 150 ml/min (STP). The temperature was recorded in the middle of the sample using a K-type thermocouple surrounded by quartz glass. CO and CO2 were continuously monitored using non-dispersive infrared spectroscopy (NDIR, X–Stream Enhanced XEGK, Emerson). In TPD, CO was exclusively detected at temperatures below 100 °C and is attributed to the desorption from the ZrO2 surface, as deduced from blank experiments using promoted and unpromoted Pt-free reference materials. However, above approx. 100 °C only CO2 was found in the gas phase. This was ascribed to the reaction of CO released from the Pt sites with the WOx/ZrO2 surface. By contrast, the blank experiments without Pt only showed negligible amounts of CO2 in accordance with investigations on Pt/TiO2 [44] and Pt/CeO2 [45]. For quantification, the detected CO2 trace was integrated, whereas the CO2 signal from the respective blank experiment (without Pt) was subtracted. With the resulting amount of CO2, attributed to CO desorbed from Pt, and an assumed CO/Pt stoichiometry of 1 [46], the amount of active Pt sites (na(Pt)) was estimated. Based on this value and the total number of Pt atoms (nPt) present in each catalyst, the dispersion of Pt (Dpt) was derived (DPt = na(pt)/nPt). The mean Pt particle size (dPt) was estimated by assuming the existence of perfect spheres: dPt = 6VPt/(aPt·DPt); VPt is the volume of a Pt atom in the bulk (15.10 Å3) and aPt representing the surface area of a Pt atom located on a polycrystalline surface (8.07 Å2) [46]. The reproducibility of the CO uptake lies in the range of approx. ± 5 %, which is in line with the accuracy of the NDIR analyzer. X-ray diffraction of powder samples (PXRD) was performed at room temperature using a D8 Discover (Bruker-AXS) with Bragg-Brentano configuration, Fe-filtered Co-Kα radiation and a VANTEC-1 detector. Diffractograms were recorded from 25to 65° in 2θ mode at a step width of 0.08° and an integration time of 8 s per step. The diffractograms were analyzed using the database Powder Diffraction Files (PDF). Laser Raman spectroscopic (LRS) analysis was performed on an InVia Raman microscope (Renishaw) using a Nd:YAG laser (532 nm, 100 mW), a grating of 1800 lines/mm and a DDC array detector. The spectra were collected in the wavenumber range from 10 to 1800 cm−1 with a resolution of 1.6 cm−1, exposure time of 3 to 20 s and laser power of 0.5 to 5 mW, accumulating 15 scans per spectrum employing WiRE 4.1 software (Renishaw). Diffuse Reflectance UV/Vis Spectroscopy (DRUV/Vis) was conducted using a Lambda 850 double-beam spectrometer with a CCD detector (Perkin Elmer) equipped with Praying Mantis reflectance optics (Harrick Scientific). The spectra were collected from 200 to 850 nm with a resolution of 1 nm and a measuring time of 0.2 s/step using UV WinLab software (Perkin Elmer). The bare ZrO2 carrier was taken as a background [47]. Note that only Pt-free samples were analyzed due to the strong absorption of Pt, which superimposes the bands of the WOx species. The DRUV/Vis spectra were processed using the Kubelka–Munk function F(R). Additionally, the optical band gap between the valence and conduction band of the WOx species was obtained by finding the intercept of the linear part of the low-energy rise of the plot (F(R)·hν)1/ n vs hν with the abscissa; n is 0.5 for allowed transitions, h is the Planck constant and ν the frequency [47–49]. Here, the valence band consists of O 2p orbitals, while the conduction band is related to W 5d (xy, yz, zx) orbitals [50] leading to the observed LMCT transitions in the ultraviolet region. 2.3 DRIFTS studies The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) studies were performed using a Tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer (Bruker) equipped with Praying Mantis reflectance optics (Harrick Scientific) and an MCT detector. The sample compartment is purged continuously with N2 to avoid the diffusion of air. The temperature-controlled IR cell made of stainless steel contained ZnSe windows and was connected to a gas-handling system. All gases were dosed using independent mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst). The spectra were recorded in the range from 900 to 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 0.9 cm−1. 300 scans were accumulated per spectrum, leading to an acquisition time of approx. 5 min. Prior to each DRIFTS experiment, the sample was placed in the sample holder and heated for 30 min at 500 °C in flowing Ar (or N2) and cooled to the desired temperature. In the studies with CO as a probe molecule, the sample was subsequently cooled to 50 °C in N2 flow, then a background spectrum was taken. After that, the sample was exposed to a mixture of 1 vol% CO and 99 vol% N2 for 15 min, followed by flushing with N2 for 30 min. Finally, the sample spectrum was taken. In the DRIFTS investigations with CO, the total gas flow was always kept at 200 ml/min (STP). Further DRIFTS investigations were made to gain mechanistic insights into the H2-deNOx reaction. One experimental approach included the sequential dosing of the reactive gas species in order to temporally separate the H2-deNOx reaction, in a manner very similar to the procedure reported previously [21,26]. For this purpose, the pretreated sample was cooled to 100 °C in Ar, then exposed to a mixture of 6 vol% O2 and 94 vol% Ar for 20 min, after which a background spectrum was taken. The following mixtures were then consecutively dosed at a total flow of 100 ml/min (STP): (a) 500 ppm NO, 6 vol% O2, 94 vol% Ar, (b) 6 vol% O2, 94 vol% Ar, (c) 100 ppm H2, 6 vol% O2, 94 vol% Ar. Spectra were taken after saturation with NO for 30 min (a) and at intervals of 20 min until the spectrum was stable upon O2/Ar exposure (b). In the final H2/O2/Ar exposure (c) spectra were recorded every 5 min for a duration of 90 min; the H2 proportion was kept at 100 ppm to avoid hot spots on the catalyst that might provoke the thermal desorption of NOx surface species. Moreover, in-situ DRIFTS studies were coupled with an online mass spectrometer (Cirrus 1, MKS Instruments) for gas phase analysis during the simultaneous supply of the reactive components, applying 100 ppm NO, 500 ppm H2 and 6 vol% O2 (Ar balance). The total gas flow was again kept at 100 ml/min (STP), while the spectra were continuously recorded. The background spectrum was recorded using a gas mixture of 6 vol% O2 and 94 vol% Ar. Subsequently, NO and H2 were simultaneously adjusted and the spectra collected to monitor the surface species present in the H2-deNOx reaction. In the MS analyses, the species with an m/z ratio of 28 (N2) and 30 (NO) was primarily checked to follow the H2-deNOx reaction. 2.4 Catalytic H2-deNOx studies The catalytic H2-deNOx investigations were performed on a laboratory test bench using a lean H2-ICE model exhaust. Before the measurements, each powder sample (200 mg) was poured into the quartz glass tube reactor (i.d. 8 mm) leading to a catalyst bed length of 3 mm, fixed with quartz wool and heated to 350 °C. Subsequently, the model exhaust was added and the temperature linearly decreased (β = 1.7 K/min) to 80 °C. The gas mixture contained 50 ppm NO, 2000 ppm H2, 13.8 vol% O2, 15.5 vol% H2O and N2 as a balance and mimics an air–fuel ratio of 2.5. An additional investigation into the role of NH3 in H2-deNOx was conducted by adding 100 ppm NH3 to the model exhaust. The total flow was always kept at 400 ml/min (STP) which corresponds to a space velocity (S.V.) of 160,000 h−1. Two dosing lines were employed. In the first line, H2, O2 and a portion of N2 (200 ml/min, STP) were added and passed over a reactor unit with Pt/Al2O3 balls heated to 220 °C for H2O production. The second line supplying NO, H2, when necessary NH3, and the remaining N2 united with the first line in front of the reactor section. All gases were controlled by independent mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst). The temperature was measured by two K-type thermocouples located directly in front of and behind the catalyst bed, respectively. The maximum difference between the inlet and outlet temperatures was 8 K. The simultaneous analysis of NO, NO2, N2O, NH3, and H2O was carried out with a hot measuring online FTIR spectrometer (MULTI-GAS Analyzer 2030, MKS Instruments). O2 was monitored using a lambda probe (LSU 4.9, Bosch). The catalysts were assessed using the conversion of NOx (X(NOx) = 1 - y(NOx)out/y(NOx)in), selectivity of N2O (S(N2O) = 2 y(N2O) / (y(NOx)in - y(NOx)out)) and NH3 (S(NH3) = y(NH3) / (y(NOx)in - y(NOx)out)). The selectivities are exclusively presented for NOx conversions above 20 % to minimize error propagation. Additionally, the gas phase proportions y(N2O) and y(NH3) are given when ammonia is dosed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physico-chemical properties of the catalysts The N2 physisorption results for the Pt catalysts show increasing BET surface areas from 61 to 95 m2/g when the W load rises from 0 to 5 wt% (Fig. 1 ). However, larger W contents (8 – 14 wt%) do not increase the BET surface area any further. The rising BET surface area at relatively low W contents is attributed to the presence of tungsten oxide on the ZrO2 surface, which inhibits the sintering of the ZrO2 support during the catalyst preparation, including a final exposure to 500 °C for 5 h [42]. The sintering is evidenced by the BET surface area decreasing from 111 m2/g for the fresh ZrO2 substrate to 61 m2/g for the annealed ZrO2 substrate. This finding is in line with the literature showing that below 600 °C the sintering of ZrO2 predominately occurs by surface diffusion, whereas existing tungsten oxide surface entities inhibit the surface mobility of ZrO2 [51,52]. Similar effects are known for CrOx and MoOx surface species on ZrO2 support materials [48,53]. At the highest W loading (14 wt%) the BET surface area is tentatively decreased to a minor extent, which may be ascribed to the significant presence of bulk tungsten oxide negligibly contributing to the surface area. A preliminary study demonstrated that bare tungsten oxide only has a BET surface area below 5 m2/g. Furthermore, the Pt dispersion determined by CO-TPD rises from 72 % to 91 % if the W load is increased from 0 to 3 and 5 wt% (Fig. 1). Since the Pt loading is kept at 0.25 wt% (related to ZrO2), the number of available Pt sites is higher for the catalyst with 5 wt% W (12 µmol/g) as compared to Pt/ZrO2 (10 µmol/g). This is obviously associated with the higher BET surface area of the 0.25/5W/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 1) [17], whereas a stabilizing effect of the WOx species on the Pt particles can also be taken into account [54]. As the W loading is further increased, the Pt dispersion decreases, reaching 49 % for the highest W content of 14 wt%, corresponding to a quantity of available Pt sites of 6.3 µmol/g. The decrease in dispersion is connected with growing Pt particle size (Table S1). In the case of the sample with 5 wt% W, for instance, the particle size amounts to 1.2 nm, while it is 2.3 nm for the sample with 14 wt% W. As the BET surface area is similar for the W loadings of 5 wt% and above, the decrease in Pt dispersion at these tungsten loadings is attributed to the fact that the ZrO2 surface is increasingly covered by larger WOx entities. As platinum is preferentially anchored to the ZrO2 surface by Lewis acid sites [55], the decreased surface area of the bare support may provoke closer proximity of the Pt atoms during the impregnation and final calcination, which may explain the Pt agglomeration that is observed [56]. However, a decoration of Pt particles by WO3 species is rather excluded as recently shown for a related W-promoted Pt sample using in-situ XPS [17]. The nature of the tungsten oxide entities is discussed in detail below (Figs. 2 – 4 ). Nevertheless, the above-stated effect of the tungsten species on the BET surface area and the Pt dispersion evidences their role as structural promoters of the Pt/W/ZrO2 samples. The XRD patterns of the bare support and the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 2) predominantly feature reflexes of monoclinic ZrO2 (PDF 97–1484) as expected from thermodynamics, whereas minor features of tetragonal ZrO2 (PDF 68–0200) are also observed. These XRD results are confirmed by LRS, showing peaks of monoclinic ZrO2 (179 cm−1, 190 cm−1, 221 cm−1, 306 cm−1, 333 cm−1, 346 cm−1, 382 cm−1, 475 cm−1, 495 cm−1, 572 cm−1, 616 cm−1, 636 cm−1) with only a weak signal assigned to the tetragonal ZrO2 (148 cm−1, Fig. 3). The diffractograms are analyzed in more detail using the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the major ZrO2 reflex at 32.8° (−111). As shown in Fig. 1 (inlay), this feature increases from 0.74 to 0.92° (2Θ) if the W loading grows from 0 to 1, 3 and 5 wt%, which is a very similar trend to the BET surface area (Fig. 1). Since the larger FWHM indicates lower crystallinity and/or smaller crystallite size, it is evident that the WOx promoter prevents the ZrO2 support from sintering and crystallizing during the final annealing step of the catalyst preparation (5 h, 500 °C). The corresponding crystallite sizes are calculated according to the Scherrer equation and are summarized in Table S1. This structural impact of the tungsten oxide also results in the stabilization of the porosity and specific surface area of the samples. It should be noted that the possible formation of a tungsten-containing ZrO2 phase, e.g. ZrW2O8, is not found for any of the catalysts regardless of the W loading. This finding is in line with the literature and is related to the different ionic radii of W6+ (0.60 Å, coordination number 6) and Zr4+ (0.84 Å, coordination number 8) [57]. Moreover, no signals attributed to Pt are detected by XRD even when the Pt loading is increased to 2 wt%. For the W-promoted catalysts, only the sample with the highest W content (14 wt%) shows additional reflexes, which are ascribed to monoclinic WO3 (PDF 43–1035). It is noteworthy that the tungsten loading of 14 wt% leads to a calculated tungsten surface concentration of 4.5 W atoms/nm2, which corresponds to the theoretical WO3 monolayer reported as 4.1 – 4.8 W atoms/nm2 for ZrO2 carriers [48,58,59]. The tungsten surface concentration was calculated as the number of W atoms (nW) present on the BET surface of the respective sample (δW, surf = nW / (SBET,cat·mCat)) without considering the existence of bulk WO3 [48] as indicated by XRD, LRS and DRUV/Vis, giving a good approximation for tungsten loadings below 14 wt%. The appearance of crystalline WO3 in this sample is substantiated by LRS (Fig. 3) based on the peaks at 699 cm−1, 800 cm−1 ((νs(W-O)) and approx. 270 cm−1 (δ(W-O-W)) [60]. Additionally, all the Pt/W/ZrO2 samples feature amorphous WOx species, which are detected between 918 and 984 cm−1 (νs(W = O)). For tungsten loadings from 1 to 11 wt%, a continuous increase in the wavenumber is observed, indicating the aggregation of the tungsten oxide species to form larger surface tungstates [47,48]. The LRS bands at 918 cm−1, 926 cm−1 and 947 cm−1 that are detected for the low W contents of 1, 3 and 5 wt% are related to isolated WO4/WO6 species [47]. However, it is not possible to distinguish between the fourfold and sixfold coordinated entities, as the characteristic LRS features overlap in this spectral range and also depend on the distortion of the WOx polyhedrons [47,48]. Additionally, the samples with W loads of 8 and 11 wt% show peaks at 885 cm−1 (νas(W = O)) and 963 cm−1 (νs(W = O)), which may be related to WO6 units existing in WyOx clusters with 12 – 18 W atoms. The DRUV/Vis spectroscopic investigations of the Pt-free W/ZrO2 samples with W contents between 1 and 14 wt% provide the optical band gap energy of the tungsten oxide entities present on the ZrO2 surface (Fig. 4); the band gap energy between the valence and conduction band was determined following the procedure described in Section 2.2. As a result, band gaps ≥ 4.5 eV are obtained for W loadings between 1 and 5 wt%, whereas with further growing W proportions they decrease to 4.4 eV (8 wt% W), 4.3 eV (11 wt% W) and 4.1 eV (14 wt% W). These band gaps correspond well with values reported for WOx-doped ZrO2 with loadings of 1 wt% (4.6 eV) and 9 wt% W (4.3 eV) [47]. The change in optical bandgap with increasing W loading and surface density is attributed to a change in the local structure of the tungstate species present on the ZrO2 surface. However, as there are a high variety of possible tungsten oxide moieties with overlapping band gaps, the WOx structures can only be estimated based upon the literature. The high energy gaps ≥ 4.5 eV for W loads between 1 and 5 wt% are tentatively assigned to distorted WO6 islands. The presence of isolated WO4 species can be excluded as the optical band gaps generally show values ≥ 5 eV [47]. The band gaps of 4.3 and 4.4 eV, found for the samples with 8 and 11 wt% W, are probably related to O3W-O-WO3 surface dimers [47]. For the catalyst with the highest W proportion (14 wt%), which has an energy gap of 4.1 eV, larger tungstate species are assumed, possibly-two-dimensional WOx chains, which include WO4 and WO6 units [47]. Overall, the increasing tungsten surface densities (δW,surf, Fig. 4) correspond well with the formation of enlarged tungsten oxide entities on the ZrO2 surface with increasing tungsten loading as observed by means of XRD, LRS and DRUV/Vis. The sample with the highest W proportion (14 wt%) features a significant fraction of crystalline WO3 domains (Fig. 3), hence its surface concentration of W is omitted. The electronic interaction between the active component Pt and the ZrO2 substrate with and without WOx promoter (W load: 0 – 14 wt%) was investigated by DRIFTS using the probe molecule CO. The resulting DRIFT spectra of the samples (Fig. 5 ) indicate that the wavenumber of the ν(CO) band increases as the W content grows. For the sample without W, the feature is located at 2071 cm−1, whereas it is shifted to 2072 cm−1 at 1 wt% W, 2075 cm−1 at 3 wt% W, 2079 cm−1 at 8 wt% W and 2085 cm−1 at 11 and 14 wt% W. The ν(CO) band is explained by CO species linearly coordinated to the Pt sites, whereas the bridging CO adsorbates expected at about 1850 cm−1 [61] are not detected in agreement with a previous study on a related Pt/W/ZrO2 sample [26]. The shift of the (CO) stretching vibration corresponds to the aggregation of the WOx entities, which is enhanced by the rising W content of the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts as derived from the above DRUV/Vis, LRS and XRD studies. The shift can therefore be attributed to a stronger electronic interaction (strong metal support interaction, SMSI) between the Pt sites and larger tungsten oxide moieties such as W12Ox – W18Ox clusters or WO3 crystallites, which are found at W loads of 8 wt% and above. It is known from the literature that larger WOx entities or WO3 crystals have a higher tendency to delocalize electrons than small isolated WO6 structures [48,62], increasing the possible electronic interaction with the Pt component. The shift in the (CO) stretching vibration to higher wavenumbers with increasing W loading (Fig. 5) is associated with an enhanced (CO) binding strength and a weakened (Pt-C) bond. This effect is explained by the decrease in the electron density of the Pt atoms caused by the larger W6+ species. However, compared to gaseous CO, whose ν(CO) band appears at approx. 2143 cm−1 [61], the (CO) binding strength of the CO adsorbates is weaker, suggesting some electron donating from the Pt sites to the π* orbitals of the CO molecules, even for the highest W load of 14 wt%. Moreover, it should also be taken into consideration that the position of the v(CO) band can also depend on the size of the Pt particles, particularly when they lie in the range of a few nanometers, as in the samples investigated in the present study (approx. 1.2 – 2.3 nm, Table S1). For instance, it is known from Pt/Al2O3 that the ν(CO) band is shifted from 2069 to 2084 cm−1 if the Pt particle size is increased from 1.3 to 2.3 nm [61]. However, when the 2Pt/5W/ZrO2 reference sample is used, which has a Pt load of 2 wt% and a mean Pt particle size of approx. 2.0 nm, the CO adsorbates have almost the same ν(CO) vibration wavenumber as the sample with a Pt content of 0.25 wt% and a mean particle size of 1.2 nm. This comparison excludes that the (CO) vibration frequency is significantly affected by the size of the Pt particles. Moreover, the area of the ν(CO) band of the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts shown in Figure S1 roughly follows the number of available Pt sites (Table S1) and the Pt dispersion (Fig. 1) respectively, i.e. the ν(CO) band area tentatively resembles the number of CO adsorbates. Note that, in contrast to the CO-TPD used to quantify the number of active Pt sites, an exact quantitative comparison of different samples is difficult with DRIFT spectroscopy, since the obtained bands depend on both absorption as well as scattering coefficients. It may be speculated that the samples, which reveal higher W loadings and larger surface tungstate species, show different IR scattering behavior as referred to the samples with smaller W contents and dispersed WOx entities. Additionally, it should be mentioned that the significant decrease in the ν(CO) band area of the samples with W contents of 11 and 14 wt% is not related to a decoration of the Pt particles by WOx moieties as shown recently by XPS investigations [17]. 3.2 H2-deNOx performance of the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts The H2-deNOx studies of the Pt/W/ZrO2 samples were conducted in a synthetic gas mixture mimicking a lean H2-ICE exhaust with 13.8 vol% O2 and 15.5 vol% H2O. To assess the catalysts, the maximum NOx conversion (X(NOx)max), the N2O selectivity at X(NOx)max (S(N2O)Xmax) and the maximum selectivity towards NH3 (S(NH3)max) are used. It may be noticed that the activity window of the catalysts is clearly affected by the proportion of the W promotor and therefore X(NOx)max and S(N2O)Xmax, respectively, and S(NH3)max refer to two different temperatures, which are shown in Table S2 for the sake of clarity. Additionally, it may be considered that the N2O selectivity at X(NOx)max is related to the H2-NO reaction on the Pt sites [26,38], whereas the maximum N2O selectivity (S(N2O)max) observed at higher temperatures (Table S2) is due to both H2-deNOx as well as NH3 oxidation as indicated in Section 3.3. Against this background X(NOx)max, S(N2O)Xmax and S(NH3)max are used to discuss the different H2-deNOx performance of the Pt/W/ZrO2 samples. Fig. 6 demonstrates that the increase in the W proportion from 0 to 5 wt% raises X(NOx)max from 61 % to 93 %, whereas S(N2O)Xmax is reduced from 42 % to 15 % and S(NH3)max from approx. 30 % to 0 %. Thus, these results clearly evidence the beneficial effect of the tungsten oxide promoter on the H2-deNOx activity and selectivity. However, when the W load is further increased, the catalytic performance weakens, as indicated by decreasing X(NOx)max and increasing S(N2O)Xmax, while NH3 is not produced at all (Fig. 6). For instance, in the case of the catalyst with the highest W loading of 14 wt%, X(NOx)max is 50 % and S(N2O)Xmax amounts to 35 %. The H2-deNOx investigations reveal that the sample with a W load of 5 wt% is most efficient due to its high X(NOx)max (93 %) and low S(N2O)Xmax (15 %) without any formation of NH3. For clarity, the performance of this catalyst and the W-free Pt/ZrO2 sample is shown over the whole temperature range (Fig. 7 ), indicating that Pt/5W/ZrO2 operates at much lower temperatures (100 – 220 °C) as indicated by the shift in X(NOx)max from 180 °C (Pt/ZrO2) to 140 °C (Pt/5W/ZrO2). Moreover, both catalysts exhibit a similar maximum N2O selectivity of 55 % (<10 ppm), which occurs at slightly higher temperatures compared to the respective maximum NOx conversion. Additionally, Pt/5W/ZrO2 exhibits a second N2O feature at approx. 120 °C, corresponding to a N2O selectivity of 18 %. Note that the H2-deNOx reaction was in a steady state, as deduced from preliminary investigations, in which selected temperatures were held constant. Moreover the mass of nitrogen has been balanced by considering N2 and N2O in previous studies using related Pt-Pd/W/ZrO2 catalysts and GC-TCD analytics (Ar balance) [21,26]. In contrast to Pt/5W/ZrO2, the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst yields NH3 below 180 °C with a maximum NH3 selectivity of approx. 30 % (7 ppm). The comparison of the H2-deNOx performance of Pt/5W/ZrO2 with W-promoted Pt catalysts reported in the literature shows that the present sample reveals a superior performance, especially below 200 °C. In particular, the high maximum NOx conversion (X(NOx)max = 93 %) and low N2O selectivity (S(N2O)Xmax = 15 %) of Pt/5W/ZrO2 is beneficial, which is related to Pt/W/SiO2/Al2O3 (X(NOx)max = 72 %, S(N2O)Xmax = 70 %) [17] and Pt/W/ZrO2 (X(NOx)max = 95 %, S(N2O)Xmax = 45 %) [26]. Unpromoted Pt/MgCeO (X(NOx)max = 94 %, S(N2O)Xmax = 20 %) [27] exhibits very similar H2-deNOx efficiency, but at a much longer residence time (S.V. = 80,000 h−1) compared to the present study (S.V. = 160,000 h−1). However, it should be noted that the y(H2)/y(NOx) ratio of 40 used in our paper is ten times the volumetric H2/NOx ratio often used in the literature (y(H2):y(NOx) = 4) [17,26,27]. Furthermore, above 220 °C, Pt/5W/ZrO2 shows only minor NOx conversion, which is attributed to the O2-rich conditions mimicking the exhaust of lean H2-ICEs. The present contents of O2 (13.8 vol%) and H2O (15.5 vol%) are relatively high compared to most investigations using far lower O2 fractions (5 – 6 vol%) [17,26,27]. As a result of this high O2 proportion, the competing reaction of H2 with O2 is enhanced, which basically limits the deNOx reaction at higher temperatures, i.e. above 220 °C. Furthermore, the effect of the electronic interaction between the W/ZrO2 substrate and the Pt component on the H2–deNOx performance is evaluated using the turnover frequency (TOF) of NOx on the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts at temperatures between 100 and 180 °C. The TOF of NOx was calculated in accordance with Eq. (1) by taking the molar amount of NOx converted per time (ṅ(NOx)) and the number of available Pt sites (nPt) deduced from CO-TPD (Table S1). The converted NOx quantity per time was obtained from Eq. (2), where Ftotal is the total gas flow, NA the Avogadro constant, X(NOx)160°C the NOx conversion at 160 °C and Vm the molar gas volume. (1) T O F = n ̇ N O x 160 ° C n P t (2) n ̇ N O x m a x = y N O x i n ∙ F t o t a l ∙ N A ∙ X N O x 160 ° C V m The obtained TOF values and the data used for Eqs. (1) and (2) are given in Table S3. For clarity, Fig. 8 exemplarily shows the turnover frequencies at 160 °C, which are representative within the low temperature region, i.e. below 200 °C. These turnover frequencies closely resemble each other (4.0·10–3 – 5.7·10-3 s−1), suggesting that the active Pt sites exhibit a very similar specific H2-deNOx activity, irrespective of the nature and amount of WOx species present in each sample. Furthermore, when the TOF is correlated with the wavenumber of the CO stretching vibration, as detected by DRIFTS after the samples are exposed to CO (Fig. 5), a clear relationship does not appear (Fig. 8). It is therefore inferred that a possible electronic activation of the Pt component by the W/ZrO2 substrate is of secondary importance for the H2-deNOx reaction. However, when the Pt dispersion is combined with the H2-deNOx activity expressed as X(NOx)max (Fig. 9 , left), it becomes evident that the NOx conversion is enhanced by an increase in the Pt dispersion. Simultaneously, the temperature, at which the maximal NOx conversion appears, decreases with increasing Pt dispersion (Fig. 9, left), which indicates acceleration of the H2-deNOx kinetics due to the increased number of active Pt sites. However, note that the turnover frequencies of NOx are not structure sensitive as already indicated in Fig. 8. It has been shown that the H2–deNOx reaction on Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts predominately takes place on the Pt sites including the elementary reactions (3) – (6) [26], while the dissociation of NO (4) [37] is the rate-determining step. The role of hydrogen is to remove chemisorbed oxygen species (O* or OH*) leading to the regeneration of active Pt sites (*) and the formation of OH* and H2O as expressed by reaction (7) and (8) [26]. (3) N O + ∗ → N O ∗ (4) N O ∗ + ∗ → N ∗ + O ∗ (5) 2 N ∗ → N 2 + 2 ∗ (6) N O ∗ + N ∗ → N 2 O + 2 ∗ (7) O ∗ + H ∗ → O H ∗ + ∗ (8) O H ∗ + H ∗ → H 2 O + 2 ∗ Thus, the higher number of available Pt sites directly enhances the NOx reduction rate, as reported for W-promoted Pt/Al2O3/SiO2 catalysts [17]. By contrast, no clear correlation is apparent between the Pt dispersion and the turnover frequency (Figure S2), indicating that the reaction rate of the active Pt site is not influenced by the dispersion. Moreover, Fig. 9 (right) shows that the N2O selectivity at maximum NOx conversion (S(N2O)Xmax) tends to decrease when the Pt dispersion rises. This trend is in line with the mechanism of the N2 and N2O formation on the Pt sites [37]. The Pt dispersion is associated with the quantity of available Pt sites, which increases from 1.3 μmol (Pt/14 W/ZrO2) to 2.4 μmol (Pt/5W/ZrO2) as deduced from Table S1. As a consequence, it is assumed that the rising amount of Pt surface atoms increases the probability for the combination of two neighboring N adsorbates (N*) to yield N2 (5). Since the N adsorbates originate from the dissociation of two NO molecules (4), the N2 formation requires four adjacent Pt atoms. By contrast, N2O is produced from one NO and N adsorbate (6), totally including only three neighboring Pt sites. Thus, the rising number of active Pt atoms may explain the observed increase in N2 selectivity. However, it should be mentioned that the increase in dispersion and active Pt sites, respectively, also results in the reduction of the particle size, which is related to a lesser number of atoms present on the surface of the individual particles. Assuming spherical particles and a Pt surface area of 8.07 Å2 [46] the number of surface atoms per Pt particle is estimated to be 56 for Pt/5W/ZrO2 (d(Pt) = 1.2 nm) and 206 for Pt/14 W/ZrO2 (d(Pt) = 2.3 nm). Nevertheless, this increased number of active Pt surface atoms of a larger particle is overcompensated by the number of smaller particles of the particle ensemble clearly providing much more active sites in total as shown above. Additionally, the combination of two adjacent N adsorbates reveals much higher frequency factor (approx. 9∙1017 mol/(m2∙s) as compared to that of the NO* + N* reaction (approx. 23 mol/(m2∙s)) as previously reported for a related Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst [37,68]; note that the frequency factors refer to the exposed Pt atoms. This increased collision probability of adjacent N adsorbates substantiates that the proximity of four Pt sites required for the dissociation of two NO molecules is a driving feature for the N2 formation. 3.3 Role of ammonia in the H2-deNOx reaction Since NH3 is observed during the NOx reduction on the Pt/ZrO2 catalysts with W loads below 5 wt% (Fig. 6), its role in the H2-deNOx reaction is investigated. The formation of NH3 can be explained with the dissociation of NO and H2 on the Pt sites, followed by the successive addition of H to an N adsorbate yielding NH, NH2 and finally NH3 surface species [63,64]. The conversion of NO and H2 adsorbates into NH and OH has also been suggested [65]. These mechanistic routes obviously suggest that the formation of NH3 is enhanced by increased NO and H coverages as well as decreased O coverage. Indeed, more NH3 is formed in H2-deNOx between 80 and approx. 180 °C when the NO fraction is increased from 50 ppm (Fig. 7) to 100 ppm and the O2 proportion is simultaneously decreased from 13.8 to 5 vol% (Figure S3) and 2 vol% (Figure S4). At temperatures above 280 °C, chemisorbed O becomes the predominate surface species in accordance with the elementary kinetic model of the H2-deNOx reaction on Pt/W/ZrO2 [26,37], thus suppressing the NH3 genesis as shown in Fig. 7 and Figures S2 – S3. Moreover, to further evaluate the different NH3 production during H2-deNOx on Pt/ZrO2 (S(NH3)max = 30 %) and Pt/5W/ZrO2 (S(NH3)max = 0 %), as demonstrated in Fig. 7, the NH3 oxidation and NH3-SCR are investigated in the presence and absence of H2 using both catalysts. The oxidation of NH3 (100 ppm) without adding H2 provides very similar traces of NOx and N2O for both catalysts as well as full NH3 conversion at temperatures above 240 °C (Figure S5). Note that the production of N2 is the thermodynamically favored path of the NH3 oxidation (4 NH3(g) + 3 O2(g) → 2 N2(g) + 6 H2O (g), ΔH0 = -1266 kJ/mol) compared to the formation of N2O (4 NH3(g) + 4 O2(g) → 2 N2O (g) + 6 H2O (g), ΔH0 = -1104 kJ/mol) and NO (4 NH3(g) + 5 O2(g) → 4 NO (g) + 6 H2O (g), ΔH0 = -907 kJ/mol), whereas N2 cannot be detected by the FTIR analyzer used. However, the main products are NOx and N2O with at most 28 ppm (S(N2O) = 56 %) at 265 °C. Additionally, NOx is increasingly produced with rising temperatures, reaching 43 ppm (S(NOx) = 43 %) at 300 °C. The NH3 storage capacity of the catalysts slightly influences the NH3 fraction in the gas phase at low temperatures. Nevertheless, the experimental results are in line with similar studies of supported Pt catalysts [66]. When the NH3 oxidation is performed in the additional presence of H2 (2000 ppm, Fig. 10 ) a distinct difference in catalytic activity is observed in comparison to experiments without H2 in the gas phase. NOx formation is detectable at temperatures as low as 130 °C in the case of the promoted sample (unpromoted: 180 °C), indicating an increase in NH3 oxidation activity with tungsten promotion. The N2O formation is very similar in the NH3 light-off range between 160 and 200 °C, with a detected N2O content of 33 ppm for the Pt/5W/ZrO2 (unpromoted: 30 ppm). The enhanced NH3 oxidation efficiency of both catalysts in the presence of H2 below 180 °C can be attributed to a local temperature increase at the reactive Pt-sites due to the strongly exothermic reaction of the H2 oxidation (2 H2 (g) + O2 (g) → 2 H2O(g), ΔH0 = -572 kJ/mol) [67] accelerating the NH3 oxidation. Simultaneously, the number of available Pt sites for NH3 oxidation is probably increased by removing chemisorbed NO* with hydrogen following the reactions (4) – (8). Note that in this experiment NO is formed by NH3 oxidation, as no NO is dosed. During H2-deNOx on unpromoted Pt/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 7) the NH3 formation only occurs at temperatures below 180 °C, which coincides with the temperature for full NH3 conversion in NH3 oxidation in the presence of H2. As no NH3 formation is observed for the tungsten-promoted Pt/ZrO2 catalyst during H2–deNOx using the same reaction conditions (Fig. 7), the enhanced NH3 oxidation in the presence of H2 (Fig. 10) is a possible explanation for the changed product selectivity of the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst in H2–deNOx, resulting in exclusive N2 and N2O output. Furthermore, the effect of NH3 on the NOx reduction was studied by adding 100 ppm NH3 to the H2-deNOx gas mixture containing y(NO) = 100 ppm and y(H2) = 2000 ppm. As a result, both catalysts show very different NH3 conversions, along with traces of NOx and N2O (Fig. 11 ). Note that the NOx formation resulting from NH3 oxidation leads to NOx proportions above the input level, preventing the calculation of NOx conversion. Additionally, the selectivity for N2O cannot be specified, as N2O can originate in NOx reduction by H2 as well as NH3 oxidation. Full NH3 conversion is achieved at similar temperatures for Pt/5W/ZrO2 (215 °C) and Pt/ZrO2 (225 °C), while the same maximal N2O yield (approx. 70 ppm, 180 °C) is obtained. The lower temperature of full NH3 conversion for Pt/5W/ZrO2 is attributed to the increased number of available Pt centers, similar to the H2-assisted NH3 oxidation (Fig. 10). The high N2O formation is in accordance with NH3-SCR studies without H2 on a polycrystalline Pt catalyst [69]. The decrease in NH3 conversion at 140 °C for the unpromoted catalyst is attributed to the NH3 formation in H2–deNOx as shown in Fig. 7. For both samples, the lowest NOx proportion is reached at 170 °C, at approx. 17 ppm NOx. Simultaneously, the temperature range of NOx reduction extends from about 140 to 280 °C. By contrast, in H2-deNOx without NH3 supply, the conversion of NOx only occurs up to 220 °C. This increase in NH3-SCR activity towards lower temperatures due to the addition of hydrogen has previously been reported for tungsten-promoted Pt/Al2O3/SiO2 catalysts [17]. Since Pt/5W/ZrO2 also has a high deNOx performance of up to 280 °C during NH3-SCR (Figure S6), the latter is ascribed to the extended activity range upon NH3-H2-NO conversion. However, the observed NOx reduction below 180 °C is clearly associated with H2-deNOx, whereas the lower temperature limit for Pt/5W/ZrO2 is also shifted to higher temperatures, namely from 100 °C to approx. 140 °C. This shift can be attributed to the higher NO content (100 ppm) and NO load, respectively, during NH3-SCR with H2 compared to H2-deNOx studies (50 ppm). Additionally, the higher NO fraction might also lead to a higher coverage of NO on the Pt sites, thus inhibiting the deNOx light-off as deduced from the elementary kinetic model of the H2-deNOx reaction on a related Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst [37]. Indeed, a H2-deNOx study performed with a NO fraction of 100 ppm confirms this decrease in low-temperature activity related to the investigation in the presence of 50 ppm NO (Figure S3). The NOx reduction by NH3 on Pt catalysts yielding N2O (NHx* + NO* →N2O + Hx*) and N2 (NHx* + NO* →N2 + OHx*) has been thoroughly investigated and involves NHx surface species (x ≤ 2) as reaction intermediates. The NHx species originate from NH3 decomposition on the Pt sites with participation of O and OH surface groups [69,70], finally resulting in the production of N2 and N2O [71,72] during the NH3-NO reaction. For the presented Pt/ZrO2 catalysts in SCR with and without W promoter (Fig. 11) a similar reaction mechanism including the formation and reaction of NHx species can be assumed due to the similar product selectivities observed. In contrast to previous studies with W-promoted Pt/ZrO2 catalysts [26] using low space velocities of 22,000 h−1, NH3 is formed during H2-deNOx using the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst when the inlet NO fraction is increased from 50 to 100 ppm at increased GHSV (Figures S2 and S3, S.V. = 160,000 h−1). Since NHx surface entities (x = 1, 2) are gradually formed during the conversion of NO into NH3 [63,64] as described above, these surface species, as well as NH3, may play a part in the NOx reduction, similar to the NH3-SCR reaction on the Pt/ZrO2 and Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 11). Moreover, studies on W-promoted Pt/Al2O3/SiO2 catalysts suggest that NHx species, formed from spill-over or readsorption of NH3 at the interface of the Pt and support, may react with NO likely adsorbed on Pt to yield N2 and H2O. The presence of tungsten oxide species increases the number of available NHx adsorption sites enhancing this reaction pathway [17]. From studies on Pt/ZrO2 catalysts promoted with Mo [86], it can further be deduced that acidic promotors such as tungsten and molybdenum oxide increase the number of strong Lewis acid sites, which act primarily as adsorption sites for NHx and NH3 participating in the SCR-related side-reaction during H2-deNOx. 3.4 DRIFTS investigations of the H2-deNOx reaction To gain further insights into the role of NH3 and NHx species in H2-deNOx, DRIFTS studies were conducted. The investigations of the H2-deNOx reaction were performed by sequential dosing of the reactive gases at 100 °C with the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst, which reveals a Pt loading of 2 wt%, to achieve enhanced band intensities due to the increased number of available Pt sites and formed adsorbates, respectively. Note that this sample shows a very similar H2–deNOx performance to the catalyst with a Pt load of 0.25 wt%, as demonstrated in Figure S7. For the temporal separation of the H2-deNOx conversion, the reactive gas species were dosed sequentially, including NO/O2/N2 exposure for 30 min (y(NO) = 500 ppm, y(O2) = 6 vol%, N2 balance) and flushing with O2/N2 for 210 min (y(O2) = 6 vol%, N2 balance) to remove weakly adsorbed species, followed by a H2/O2/N2 supply. The H2 content was set to 100 ppm to avoid local hot spots due to the exothermic H2 oxidation [67]. Representative DRIFT spectra obtained immediately before the H2 dosage (t = 0 min) and after the H2 was supplied for 10, 60 and 90 min are depicted in Fig. 12 . The spectrum prior to the H2 supply is used to identify the different species adsorbed on the catalyst surface after saturation and flushing. The band observed at 1780 cm−1 is associated with the (NO) stretching vibration of NO molecules linearly bound to Pt sites [26,61]. This assignment is in line with a preliminary NO adsorption study of the Pt-free 5 W/ZrO2 substrate, showing no DRIFTS feature above 1650 cm−1. Additionally, the strong bands between 1500 and 1650 cm−1 are related to nitrato surface species bound to the support. Bands at 1610 cm−1, 1585 cm−1 and 1541 cm−1 are generally attributed to bidentate bridging nitrate (ν(NO)), monodentate and bidentate chelate-bound NO3 – (ν(NO)) with the corresponding asymmetric stretching vibrations (νas(NO2)) detected at 1240 cm−1 and 1291 cm−1 (shoulder) [73–77]. However, the exact assignment of the nitrate species remains difficult due to the broad bands observed. During flushing with O2/N2 (Figure S9), all bands ascribed to NO3 – show similar band growth with exposure times supporting the assignment. The band at 1191 cm−1 is tentatively related to nitrite (ν(NO)) [73,76,77]. Note that nitrite species are not clearly detectable when the catalyst is exposed to NO at 150 °C and above due to their low thermal stability in the presence of O2 [74]. Additionally, the 1191 cm−1 band is seen to decrease in intensity with simultaneous band growth of the nitrate species (1500 – 1650 cm−1) at 100 °C during the purging phase (Figure S9). As oxygen is present in the gas phase during purging (y(O2) = 6 vol%, N2 balance), the oxidation of nitrite to form nitrate species is likely. In the literature, however, bands at 1191 cm−1 have also been assigned to monodentate or bidentate nitrate [73,78] or anionic nitrosyl [75,79]. When H2 is dosed, additional DRIFTS bands appear in the OH stretching vibration range above 3000 cm−1. The bands from 3690 to 3770 cm−1 are related to OH species coordinated either to one, two or three to Zr4+ and/ or W6+ cations. By contrast, a broad band from 3200 to 3600 cm−1 is related to hydrogen-bonded OH groups present in molecular H2O and OH– [80,81]. The band at 1610 cm−1 increases strongly when hydrogen is added to the gas phase, while the band at 1585 cm−1 grows only slightly. This is related to the superposition of the nitrato surface species (1500 – 1650 cm−1) by the deformation vibration of water (1620 cm−1) originating in the H2 oxidation, which is shifted upon adsorption on ZrO2 to around 1610 cm−1 [26,74,75,79,82]. Simultaneously, the bands related to hydrogen-bonded OH groups of molecular water and OH– rise due to the increased presence of H2O formed by H2 oxidation. The bands at 1240 cm−1, 1291 cm−1 and 1541 cm−1 attributed to nitrate species show no change even after H2 dosing for 90 min, making the participation of NO3 – species in H2–deNOx unlikely. However, the bands at 1780 cm−1 (NO-Pt) and 1191 cm−1 (NO2 –) decrease during the H2 supply. The decrease in the 1780 cm−1 band is interpreted as being related to the NO reduction by H2 on the Pt sites by the dissociative adsorption of NO as described in Section 3.3 and as indicated for Pt/Al2O3 [38] and a related Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst [26]. A rapid decrease to approx. 60 % of the band intensity assigned to a nitrite compound at 1191 cm−1 is already observed after 10 min of H2 dosing, while all other bands remain unchanged. After 60 min, the band at 1191 cm−1 has completely vanished. This decrease is attributed to an oxidative conversion of the nitrite adsorbate to nitrate species, as observed during the purge phase. It is likely that, even at the low hydrogen content applied (y(H2) = 100 ppm), the exothermic H2 oxidation leads to very slightly increased temperatures at the catalyst surface similarly to a recent study on a monolithic H2-deNOx catalyst using higher H2 contents [67,83]. Moreover, as the nitrite species are not temperature-stable, as found in prior experiments at increased temperatures (150 °C), it is possible that a local temperature increase leads to enhanced conversion of the nitrite species to nitrate. However, it cannot be completely excluded that this nitrite species is also reduced by H2. The reactivity of NOx species adsorbed on the support and the interface between the support and the Pt site is a postulated reaction mechanism for various Pt-based catalysts (e.g. Pt/Na/ZSM-5 [13], Pt/MgO-CeO2 [28]) known from the literature. The hydrogen spills over to the support after dissociative adsorption on the Pt site and subsequently reacts with the adsorbed NOx species [28]. It is noteworthy that no evidence has been found for a postulated mechanism of the H2–deNOx reaction involving the formation of ammonia species on Brønsted acid centers (NH4 +) on the catalyst surface, which are reported at 1445 cm−1 (σas(NH4 +)) and 1660 cm−1 (σs(NH4 +)) as an intermediate during NH3-SCR [29,31]. In-situ DRIFTS investigations were performed at 100 and 150 °C using online mass spectroscopy during the simultaneous dosage of the reactive gases to analyze the species with a m/z ratio of 28 (N2), and 30 (NO) and thus to confirm the catalyst activity in the H2-deNOx reaction. In contrast to the DRIFTS studies with sequential gas dosing, this approach includes H2-deNOx under steady-state conditions (t = 30 min). Fig. 13 shows that the in-situ spectra recorded at 100 and 150 °C are similar. One exception is the band at 1020 cm−1, which is only detected at 150 °C; this feature is related to bidentate chelate-bound NO3 – (νs(NO2)) [73–77], possibly originating in the stronger NO2 formation on the catalyst compared to 100 °C [74]. The remaining DRIFTS signals are assigned as in the study with the sequential gas supply. Moreover, the band intensity of Pt-NO (1780 cm−1) is strongly diminished while the band intensities of OH and H2O species (3000 – 3600 cm−1) are significantly lower at 150 °C due to the enhanced thermal desorption. By contrast, the nitrate bands (1500 – 1650 cm−1, 1200 – 1300 cm−1) are more intense at 150 °C, possibly due to the lower surface coverage by molecular water, providing more adsorption sites for NOx or stronger NO2 formation, as indicated by the band at 1020 cm−1 attributed to bidentate chelate-bound NO3 –. This behavior is in agreement with a previous work on related Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts [26]. Unlike the case of sequential dosing at 100 °C, no nitrite compound (1191 cm−1) is observed, which can be attributed to the facile oxidative conversion of these NO2 – species to nitrates on the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst upon local temperature increases induced by H2 oxidation as described above. Note that no bands ascribable to NHx (x = 1–3) or NH4 + species are detected during the in-situ DRIFTS studies (Fig. 12). Thus, there is no unambiguous proof of an additional pathway for the NOx reduction provided by NHx or NH4 + surface entities. However, the presence of reactive NHx species is very likely, as deduced from NH3 formation during H2-deNOx on the Pt/ZrO2 and Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalysts, conducted with the same NO fraction of 100 ppm but a higher H2 content of 2000 ppm (Figure S3 and S4), and their NH3-SCR performance (Fig. 11). It should be noted that with higher H2 contents such as 2000 and 4000 ppm, very similar DRIFT spectra are obtained. To establish that ammonia formed during H2-deNOx can be detected and to determine the respective adsorption sites of ammonia species, a tungsten-free Pt/ZrO2 catalyst is investigated as a reference case. In contrast to the tungsten-promoted Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst, this sample shows substantial NH3 formation under experimental conditions similar to those selected for DRIFTS investigations (Figure S8). The in-situ spectrum of the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst after reaching a steady state (t = 30 min) is shown exclusively for 150 °C (Fig. 14 ), as online mass spectroscopy showed neither NO reduction (m/z = 30) nor N2 formation (m/z = 28) at 100 °C. The band assignment of nitrate species (1020 cm−1, 1252 cm−1, 1294 cm−1, 1541 cm−1, 1610 cm−1) and water (1610 cm−1) is analogous to the in-situ investigation using the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 13). It is noteworthy that the band ascribed to the (NO) stretching vibration of NO species linearly bound to Pt is slightly shifted to 1774 cm−1 compared to the W-promoted sample (1780 cm−1). The strengthened (NO) bond indicates a weakened Pt-N bond that is attributed to a lower electron density at the Pt sites after tungsten promotion, as detected by DRIFTS experiments using CO as a probe molecule (Fig. 5). The weakened Pt-N bond is tentatively interpreted with a lower NO coverage of the Pt sites, which is supported by the clearly decreasing area of the ν(NO) band from 0.78 cm−1 to 0.29 cm−1. The rate-determining step for the H2-deNOx reaction on a Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst [26] is the dissociative adsorption of NO [37], which requires two adjacent Pt sites. Applying this reasoning to the presented Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst, slightly lower NO coverages may cause more free Pt sites, on which more hydrogen can dissociatively adsorb leading to higher NOx conversions during H2–deNOx as expressed by reactions (3) – (8) [37]. Note that in accordance with the calculation of the TOF numbers (Fig. 8), the rate-determining step in H2–deNOx is accelerated not by the change in Pt-N bond strength but by the number of active Pt sites available. The increased number of free platinum centers also enhances the ammonia oxidation, which may add to the decreased NH3 formation under the O2-rich H2-deNOx conditions on the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst. The Pt/ZrO2 catalyst also shows a distinct band at 1190 cm−1, which is not detected for the W-promoted sample during in-situ DRIFTS and has been tentatively assigned to nitrite (ν(NO)) in the DRIFTS study performed with sequential gas dosing. The band at 1582 cm−1, previously assigned to the chelating NO3 – (ν(NO)), is also strongly pronounced and exceeds the adjacent bands at 1541 cm−1 (bidentate chelate-bound NO3 – ν(NO)) and 1610 cm−1 (bidentate bridging nitrate (ν(NO)). Blank experiments using 1000 ppm NH3 in N2 (30 min) and subsequent flushing with N2 (45 min) at 50 °C, 100 °C and 150 °C (Figure S10) show DRIFTS bands at 1602 cm−1 (δas(NH3)) and 1168 – 1179 cm−1 (δs(NH3)). It is known from literature that NH3 molecularly adsorbed on Zr4+ provides bands at approx. 1600 cm−1 (δas(NH3)), 1195 cm−1 and 1151 cm−1 (δs(NH3)), whereas NH3 hydrogen bonded to Zr4+ shows deformation vibration bands at 1600 cm−1 (δas(NH3)) and 1123 cm−1 (δs(NH3)) [84,85]. Therefore, the bands at 1190 cm−1 and 1582 cm−1 found in the in-situ DRIFTS studies of the H2–deNOx reaction are tentatively assigned as NH3 coordinated to Zr4+ (H3N-Zr4+). This assignment is supported by the simultaneous growth of both bands during the dosing of the reactive gases during H2-deNOx (not shown). However, as the bands of nitrate and nitrite species overlap with the bands of NH3 species, an unequivocal assignment is rather difficult. In contrast to the literature, the formation of ammonia in the H2-deNOx reaction, coordinated to Brønsted acid centers (NH4 +) on the catalyst surface as detected at 1445 cm−1 (σas(NH4 +)) and 1660 cm−1 (σs(NH4 +)) [29,31], cannot be detected. This may be because the ammonia bound to the Brønsted acid sites is replaced by H2O formed during the H2 oxidation. It has been suggested that the favored H2O adsorption is due to the stronger polarity of the OH bond in the water molecule in comparison to the NH bond in ammonia, forming a stronger hydrogen bond [85]. 4 Conclusion The lean H2-deNOx performance of the W-modified Pt/ZrO2 catalysts, including W loads from 0 to 14 wt%, was mostly affected by the structural promotion of the tungsten oxide component. The best performance was achieved for a W loading of 5 wt% associated with isolated WO6 islands, which stabilize the specific surface area of the ZrO2, leading to the highest number of available Pt sites. At higher W loads, the availability of Pt sites dropped considerably as the ZrO2 surface was increasingly covered with the larger WOx entities. Consequently, the surface area decreased and the Pt particles aggregated. Furthermore, a relatively moderate electronic interaction between the Pt and WOx promoter appeared particularly at high W loads, reflecting W12Ox – W18Ox clusters and WO3 crystallites, respectively. As a result of this weak electronic interaction, somewhat similar turnover frequencies were obtained for the different Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts. It should also be mentioned that the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst with a W loading of 5 wt% shows high performance even after hydrothermal exposure for up to 96 h at 600 °C as demonstrated in Figure S11. Additionally, NH3 formation in the H2-deNOx reaction was observed on Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts at W loadings below 5 wt%. For higher W contents, the NH3 output decreased due to stronger NH3 oxidation activity, which might be affected by the lower electron density of the Pt atoms. Moreover, in-situ DRIFTS studies using the Pt/W/ZrO2 catalyst with 5 wt% W showed that the NOx reduction by H2 on the Pt sites is the predominate reaction path. However, it was also suggested that NHx species formed at the interface of Pt and support additionally participate in line with a SCR-related mechanism that takes place on the bare and W-promoted Pt/ZrO2 surface. Overall, the Pt/5W/ZrO2 catalyst provides a maximal NOx conversion up to 94 % and a N2O selectivity below 15 % in synthetic exhaust gas with typical compositions for lean H2 combustion engines. The activity window is located in the low-temperature region from 100 to 200 °C, making H2-deNOx conversion a possible solution for efficient NOx reduction in O2-rich H2 combustion engines, as current technologies such as SCR only operate above these temperatures. However, lowering the N2O selectivity remains a major challenge for the exhaust gas after-treatment using the H2-deNOx technique. coredata.dc:description: This work addresses the reduction of NOx by H2 under O2-rich conditions below 200 °C using Pt/W/ZrO2 catalysts with tungsten loadings from 0 to 14 wt%. Samples were thoroughly characterized by N2 physisorption, temperature-programmed desorption of CO, X-ray diffraction, laser Raman spectroscopy and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) with CO as probe molecule. Catalytic investigations showed the highest efficiency for the sample with 5 wt% W providing NOx conversion of 94 % and N2O selectivity of 15 %. The effect of W promoter is mostly attributed to structural promotion by isolated WO6 entities stabilizing the ZrO2 surface and leading to a high number of active Pt sites. By contrast, negligible electronic interaction between the promoter and Pt sites appears. Moreover, DRIFTS studies suggest that, in addition to the predominate NOx reduction by H2 on Pt sites, a side reaction occurs including NHx species formed at the interface of Pt and WOx/ZrO2.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting effect exerted by WOx on Pt/ZrO2 catalysts during NOx reduction using H2 in the excess of O2
